contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=June 2010}} {{Expand German|Wendehals (Vogel)|fa=yes|topic=sci|date=December 2009}} {{Taxobox| name = Eurasian Wryneck | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref>{{IUCN|id=100600538 |title=''Jynx torquilla'' |assessors=[[BirdLife International]] |version=2012.1 |year=2012 |accessdate=16 July 2012}}</ref> | image = Jynx torquilla vlaskop cropped.jpg | image_width = 250px | range_map = Jynx torquilla distr .png | range_map_caption = <br/>{{legend0|#F7A229|Summer|border=solid 1px black}} {{legend0|#53A27B|Resident|border=solid 1px black}} {{legend0|#5379F6|Winter|border=solid 1px black}} | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordata]] | classis = [[Bird|Aves]] | ordo = [[Piciformes]] | familia = [[Picidae]] | subfamilia = [[Jynginae]] | genus = ''[[Wryneck|Jynx]]'' | species = '''''J. torquilla''''' | binomial = ''Jynx torquilla'' | binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|Linnaeus]], [[10th edition of Systema Naturae|1758]] }} The '''Eurasian Wryneck''' (''Jynx torquilla'') is a species of [[wryneck]] in the family of [[woodpecker]]s. This species breeds in temperate regions of [[Europe]] and [[Asia]]. It is [[bird migration|migratory]], wintering in tropical [[Africa]] and southern [[Asia]] from [[Iran]] to the [[Indian Subcontinent]]. It is a bird of open woodland and orchards. On migration it is frequently seen in sandy areas, where it forages for [[ant]]s. [[Image:Jinxtorquilla.jpg|left|thumb]] [[Image:Wryneck.ogv|left|thumb|Wryneck twisting its neck]] This species measure {{convert|16|-|18|cm|in|abbr=on}} in length and weighs {{convert|26|-|50|g|oz|abbr=on}}.<ref name = "CRC">''CRC Handbook of Avian Body Masses'' by John B. Dunning Jr. (Editor). CRC Press (1992), ISBN 978-0-8493-4258-5.</ref> Their bills are shorter and less dagger-like than in the other woodpeckers, but their chief prey is [[ant]]s and other insects, which they find in decaying wood or almost bare soil. They re-use woodpecker holes for nesting, rather than making their own holes. The eggs are white, as with many hole nesters. These [[bird]]s get their [[English language|English]] name from their ability to turn their heads almost 180 degrees. When disturbed at the nest, they use this [[snake]]-like head twisting and hissing as a threat display. This odd behaviour led to their use in witchcraft, hence to put a "[[jinx]]" on someone. They nest in existing holes.They lay 7 to 10 eggs on May-June There are six subspecies: * ''Jynx torquilla chinensis'' Hesse, 1911 * ''Jynx torquilla himalayana'' Vaurie, 1959 * ''Jynx torquilla mauretanica'' Rothschild, 1909 * ''Jynx torquilla sarudnyi'' Loudon, 1912 * ''Jynx torquilla torquilla'' Linnaeus, 1758 * ''Jynx torquilla tschusii'' O. Kleinschmidt,1907 ==External links== {{Reflist}} *{{Commons category-inline|Jynx torquilla}} *{{wikispecies-inline|Jynx torquilla}} *{{field guide birds of the world|Jynx torquilla}} *{{avibase|B2E6AB9FC2608DFA|Jynx torquilla}} *[http://www.oiseaux.net/birds/photos/wryneck.html Oiseaux] Photos *[http://www.ibercajalav.net/img/287_WryneckJtorquilla.pdf Ageing and sexing (PDF) by Javier Blasco-Zumeta] [[Category:Woodpeckers]] [[Category:Birds of Europe]] [[Category:Birds of Asia]] [[Category:Birds of Africa]] [[Category:Birds of Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Birds of Iran]] [[Category:Witchcraft]] [[Category:Birds of Western Sahara]] [[Category:Birds of Cameroon]] [[Category:Birds of Nepal]] {{woodpecker-stub}} {{Link FA|de}}
